Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The relative importance of species, genotype, and trait diversity on ecosystem function of the tall grass prairie under varying environmental conditions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the importance of biological diversity is critical in the face of unprecedented, anthropogenic global change such as increased introduction of invasive species and land-use change. This research consists of two greenhouse experiments that will provide insight into how diversity is maintained in grasslands, and why this diversity could be important to ecosystem functions such as productivity and invasion resistance. The first experiment will establish competition among genetically distinct individuals to understand how diversity is maintained within a dominant native grass. The second experiment will examine how this genetic diversity prevents establishment of different native and invasive seedlings.

Results from this project will inform the preservation of biodiversity, prevention of species invasions, and the enhancement of carbon sequestration in grasslands, an economically and ecologically valuable ecosystem. Results will also be integrated into local environmental education programs to emphasize the importance of preserving biodiversity in native ecosystems. The project will give undergraduate and underrepresented high school students access to hands-on learning about the research process, allowing them to connect scientific research on a growing environmental problem. Finally, funding this project will train a young female scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project description

Understanding the importance of biological diversity is critical in the face of unprecedented, anthropogenic global change. This study consists of large greenhouse experiment that complements a series of field studies and will provide insight into how diversity is maintained in grasslands, and why this diversity could be important to ecosystem function such as productivity. To understand how diversity within a dominant native grass is maintained, we competed 4 of the most common genotypes (genetically unique individuals) found in the field under controlled conditions in the greenhouse with different amounts of light, water, and nitrogen availability. We found that different genotypes perform better under low resource conditions in competition, which helps explain how these genotypes coexist under natural field conditions.

 

Project outcomes

The results of this study have been presented in the annual Ecological Society of America conference (August 2011), the annual Konza Prairie LTER workshop (April 2011), and International Grassland Symposium (Sept 2011). In addition, I (co-PI Cynthia Chang) have gained the experience mentoring and supervising one high school student, one undergraduate student, and one post-Masters student. I have taught them basic scientific skills, experimental design, and basic biology of this dominant grass. With the high school student, I taught him basic statistics to analyze the data that we were collecting throughout the summer together. In addition, I showed him basic molecular techniques from research that complemented the greenhouse study. These interactions have been mutually beneficial. This study has exposed these students to ecological research and hopefully fostering interest in science, while I gained the opportunity to develop mentoring and teaching skills which will be beneficial in a future career in science.
